title: 111_s2901
content: The "Acquisition Workforce Improvement Act of 2009" establishes the Government-Wide Acquisition Management Fellows Program under the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act. The Acquisition Workforce Improvement Act of 2009 establishes a government-wide acquisition management fellows program to invest in the long-term improvement of the Federal acquisition workforce by developing new leaders with government-wide perspective and recruiting individuals with outstanding academic backgrounds. The program aims to develop new acquisition leaders with government-wide perspective, recruit individuals with academic merit and leadership skills, and provide advancement opportunities in executive agencies. The program aims to develop new acquisition leaders with government-wide perspective, recruit individuals with academic merit and leadership skills, and provide advancement opportunities in executive agencies. Upon completion, participants will have opportunities for advancement, competitive compensation, and leadership roles at various executive agencies through contracts with qualified universities for training. Government acquisition program includes one academic year of on-campus training followed by two years of on-the-job training towards a Masters degree. The curriculum involves rotational assignments at executive agencies covering acquisition planning, cost estimation, and contract administration. The executive agencies cover acquisition planning, cost estimation, and contract administration for various types of contracts, emphasizing transparency and accountability. Training includes courses required for a basic contracting officer warrant. The program includes courses on basic contracting officer warrant, transparency, accountability, and integrity in public contracting. Graduates receive priority for employment in the acquisition field based on their performance. The program prioritizes graduates for hiring in the acquisition field at GS-12, 13, or 14 levels based on their performance. The program limits the total number of participants to 200 per year, with a minimum of 50 in the first year, 100 in the second year, and 150 in subsequent years. Hiring must comply with merit system principles and not infringe on the rights of preference eligible individuals. The program limits participants to 200 per year, with a minimum of 50 in the first year, 100 in the second year, and 150 thereafter. The Administrator must enter contracts with qualified universities for program management. The program requires cooperative agreements with universities specializing in Federal Government acquisition, responsible for program management, participant selection, and career development review post-graduation. The program requires cooperative agreements with universities specializing in Federal Government acquisition for participant selection and career development review post-graduation. Selected participants must commit to federal employment in acquisition after program completion. Participants in the program must commit to working for the Federal Government in acquisition for a minimum term of one year for each year in the program. Candidates who do not complete the program or meet service requirements must reimburse the government for funds received. Candidates who do not successfully complete the program or meet service requirements must reimburse the Federal Government for funds received. A fund called the OFPP Acquisition Fellows Development Fund is established for the program's operations. The 'Acquisition Fellows Development Fund' (referred to as the `Fund') is used for the program's establishment and operations, awarding contracts, grants, or cooperative agreements for student expenses like tuition, books, room and board, and travel. The 'Acquisition Fellows Development Fund' covers academic expenses, room and board, travel expenses, stipends, program planning and administration, and other necessary expenses as determined by the Administrator. The Fund is funded through appropriations or other available sources. The 'Acquisition Fellows Development Fund' covers academic expenses, room and board, travel expenses, stipends, program planning, administration, and other necessary expenses as determined by the Administrator. The Fund is funded through appropriations or other available sources. The Fund shall consist of amounts appropriated or otherwise made available to the Fund. The government-wide acquisition management fellows program under section 45 of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act requires the Administrator to submit an initial report within 120 days of enactment and annual reports thereafter. The Administrator must submit an annual report to congressional committees on the government-wide acquisition management fellows program, detailing activities, participant numbers, training provided, and program effectiveness. The annual report on the government-wide acquisition management fellows program must include participant numbers, training details, program effectiveness assessment, university performance, and recommendations for legislative or administrative actions. The annual report on the government-wide acquisition management fellows program must include participant numbers, training details, program effectiveness assessment, university performance, and recommendations for legislative or administrative actions, as deemed appropriate by the Administrator. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The OFPP Acquisition Fellows Development Fund is authorized to receive appropriations of $16,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, $32,000,000 for fiscal year 2012, and $48,000,000 for fiscal year 2013. This funding is overseen by specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives.
